context: These Are My Children | These Are My Children is an American television soap opera which ran on NBC from January 31, 1949, to February 25, 1949. The show was broadcast live from Chicago, Illinois, airing fifteen minutes a day, five days a week, at 5:00 p.m. EST. It is widely credited as the first soap opera broadcast on television. It may be more accurately described as the first daytime drama or the first soap opera strip, as it was preceded by DuMont series "Faraway Hill" in 1946 and "Highway to the Stars" in 1947, both of which are described as soap operas but aired later in the evenings and broadcast only once a week.

Baby colic | Baby colic, also known as infantile colic, is defined as episodes of crying for more than three hours a day, for more than three days a week, for three weeks in an otherwise healthy child. Often crying occurs in the evening. It typically does not result in long term problems. The crying can cause frustration for the parents, depression following delivery, excess visits to the doctor, and child abuse.

Breastfeeding | Breastfeeding, also known as nursing, is the feeding of babies and young children with milk from a woman's breast. Health professionals recommend that breastfeeding begin within the first hour of a baby's life and continue as often and as much as the baby wants. During the first few weeks of life babies may nurse roughly every two to three hours. The duration of a feeding is usually ten to fifteen minutes on each breast. Older children feed less often. Mothers may pump milk so that it can be used later when breastfeeding is not possible. Breastfeeding has a number of benefits to both mother and baby, which infant formula lacks.

Atlantic Air BVI | Atlantic Air BVI (AABVI) started up in 1992 with one Shorts 330-200 (VP-LVR). AABVI ran a service from Tortola, BVI to San Juan, Puerto Rico 5 times a day, 7 days a week. On 6 May 1993 the Shorts experienced an aborted take off and ran off the end of the runway into Trellis Bay.
demos.question: My baby has been pooing 5-6 times a day for a week. In the last few days it has increased to 7 and they are very watery with green stringy bits in them. He does not seem unwell i.e no temperature and still eating. He now has a very bad nappy rash from the pooing ...help!
demos.rationale:
It seems like your baby might be experiencing gastrointestinal issues, possibly due to an imbalance or change in their diet. While it is not uncommon for babies to have increased bowel movements and changes in stool consistency, the presence of green stringy bits could indicate a possible intestinal infection or other digestive concerns.

Here are some steps you can take:

1. Consult your pediatrician: Schedule an appointment with your baby's doctor to discuss their symptoms and get professional advice on the best course of action. They may recommend further tests, such as a stool sample analysis or blood work, to determine the cause of these changes in bowel movements.

2. Review dietary habits: Evaluate any recent changes in your baby's diet that could be contributing to their symptoms. This includes breastfeeding mothers ensuring they are consuming a well-balanced and nutritious diet, as this can affect the quality of breast milk.

3. Monitor for other signs: Keep an eye on your baby's overall health and behavior. If you notice any additional symptoms such as fever, vomiting, loss of appetite, or lethargy, seek medical attention immediately.

4. Manage nappy rash: To help alleviate the discomfort caused by the increased bowel movements and subsequent nappy rash, gently clean your baby's bottom with warm water after each diaper change. Apply a barrier cream or ointment to protect their skin from further irritation.

5. Stay hydrated: Ensure that your baby is drinking enough fluids throughout the day to help prevent dehydration, especially if they are experiencing watery stools. Breast milk and formula should be sufficient for most babies in this age group. However, consult with a pediatrician if you have concerns about their hydration levels.

Remember that while these steps can help manage your baby's symptoms, it is essential to seek professional medical advice to determine the underlying cause and appropriate treatment plan.
demos.answer:
It sounds like your little one may be experiencing some gastrointestinal discomfort due to changes in their bowel movements. While this isn't uncommon for babies, the presence of green stringy bits could indicate a possible intestinal issue or imbalance. Here are steps you can take:

1. Schedule an appointment with your pediatrician: It is essential to consult your baby's doctor as soon as possible to discuss their symptoms and receive professional advice on the best course of action. The doctor may recommend further tests, such as a stool sample analysis or blood work, to determine the cause of these changes in bowel movements.

2. Review dietary habits: Take note of any recent changes in your baby's diet that could be contributing to their symptoms. If you are breastfeeding, ensure that you maintain a well-balanced and nutritious diet as it can affect the quality of your milk.

3. Monitor for other signs: Keep an eye on your baby's overall health and behavior. Look out for additional symptoms such as fever, vomiting, loss of appetite, or lethargy, which may require immediate medical attention.

4. Manage nappy rash: To help alleviate the discomfort caused by increased bowel movements and subsequent nappy rash, gently clean your baby's bottom with warm water after each diaper change. Apply a barrier cream or ointment to protect their skin from further irritation.

5. Stay hydrated: Ensure that your baby is drinking enough fluids throughout the day to prevent dehydration, especially if they are experiencing watery stools. Breast milk and formula should be sufficient for most babies in this age group; however, consult with a pediatrician if you have concerns about their hydration levels.

Remember that while these steps can help manage your baby's symptoms, it is crucial to seek professional medical advice to determine the underlying cause and appropriate treatment plan.

demos.question: I am F 38 in good shape work out (do triathlons) regular but have had back pain from different reasons throughout my life now I every so often wake up with severe lower back, hip pain for no reason. today the pain is almost taking my breathe away when i move. It is a dull pain when i am just lying down but the moment I make any sort of movement I have sharp and sometimes shooting pain down my legs.
demos.answer: Hi, From history it seems that you might be having degenerative changes in your lower back spines giving pinched nerve pressure. There might be having osteomalacia or osteoporosis as well. Go for x-ray lumbosacral region for osteoarthritis. Physiotherapy like back extension exercises will be much helpful. Take B1, B6, B!2 shots or medicine. Take calcium, vitamin A and D supplements. Ok and take care.
